questions.text: What is the most important pathophysiological factor implicated in GERD?
questions.solution:
Frequent transient lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation accounts for more than 90% of the cases of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a condition that develops when there is a retrograde flow of stomach contents back into the esophagus. It can present as non-erosive reflux disease or erosive esophagitis.

A hiatal hernia is the next common cause of GERD. Factors contributing to the high pressure in the LES zone:

Factors contributing to the high pressure in the LES zone: 

  • Intrinsic musculature of the distal esophagus and sling fibers of the cardia of stomach which are in tonic contraction
  • During inspiration, the anterposterior diameter of the crural opening of diaphragm is decreased (increases LES pressure)
  • Transmitted pressure of the abdominal cavity on the LES zone

questions.text: Which of the following foods will you recommend to a patient to reduce symptoms of GERD?
questions.solution:
Protein increases the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure, thereby allowing the closure of the sphincter and reducing reflux. 

Other options:

Option A: Chocolate and coffee both contain methylxanthine, which causes muscles to relax and lowers the LES pressure. In addition, coffee can stimulate gastric secretions, which can promote reflux. 

Option C:  Fatty foods have been found to delay gastric emptying and decrease the LES pressure, thereby prolonging the esophageal exposure time to the stomach acid and the volume available for reflux.

Option D: Alcohol, mint, citrus, tomatoes, and/or carbonated beverages may cause further irritation to the damaged esophageal mucosa but have not been found to cause reflux themselves.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a feeling of fullness and sensation of a lump in the throat for the past 3 weeks. He has no other complaints like weight loss or dysphagia. Rigid endoscopy showed no growth or foreign body in the throat. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Lump in the throat only felt during swallowing
Does not interfere with eating or drinking

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of globus hystericus. It is a feeling of fullness or lump in the throat that is felt always and not only when swallowing.

Globus hystericus or globus pharyngeus is a persistent abnormal sensation in the throat in the absence of any observable pathology. The exact cause of globus sensation is uncertain. The sensation is often relieved by the act of swallowing and it does not interfere with eating and drinking.

Examination and investigations may be carried out to exclude any other underlying problem. It is often attributable to GERD. Reassurance that there is no serious underlying problem may be all that is needed in terms of treatment.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented to the physician with complaints of heartburn and a sour taste in the mouth for the past 1 year. He was prescribed proton pump inhibitors, but the symptoms did not improve. What is the immediate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of dyspepsia not responding to PPIs. So the best management for this patient is endoscopy.

In case of an unexplained dyspepsia

  • If the patient is >60 years - Endoscopy is the investigation of choice 
  • If the patient is <60 years - A test for H.pylori infection is done (stool antigen and urease breath test) and eradication treatment is given. Endoscopy is done only if any one of the alarming signs are present.

Alarming signs

  1. Odynophagia or dysphagia
  2. Unexplained weight loss
  3. Massive GI bleeding
  4. Recurrent vomiting
  5. Jaundice
  6. Palpable mass or adenopathy
  7. Family history of GI malignancy

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved by loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an intrathoracic gas bubble. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with X-ray findings showing a retrocardiac gas bubble are consistent with the diagnosis of a hiatus hernia. A CT scan with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis. It highlights the gastric anatomy but also helps to identify other structures involved in the hiatal hernia.

Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1- sliding hernia

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.

Type 2- rolling hiatus hernia:

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia.

Clinical features:

  • Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.

Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.

Type 3- mixed hiatus hernia:

A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia:

Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

Note: This is a controversial question as some books give barium swallow as the investigation of choice for hiatal hernia. But Bailey's 28th edition clearly mentions that a CT scan with oral contrast is the answer.

The image below shows a retrocardiac gas bubble on an X-ray that is consistent with hiatus hernia.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of Nissen's fundoplication?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is gas-bloat syndrome. 

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus.

After this procedure, most patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the esophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach resulting in bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. This is known as gas bloat syndrome and occurs more commonly with Nissen total fundoplication.

Pneumothorax is the most common complication that occurs intraoperatively.

questions.text: The fundus is wrapped (270 degrees) around the posterior aspect of the esophagus in which of the following corrective procedures for GERD?
questions.solution:
Partial posterior fundoplication between 180 to 270 degrees is called Toupet fundoplication.

It is used in the surgical management of GERD. Partial anterior fundoplication is Dor’s fundoplication and total fundoplication is Nissen’s fundoplication.

questions.text: What is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
Leiomyomas are the most common benign tumors of the esophagus.

Leiomyomas are benign tumors that arise from the muscularis propria. They are found in the mid to distal esophagus.

They are more common in males and small, asymptomatic lesions are observed, while symptomatic lesions are enucleated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
Barrett’s esophagus is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the lower end of the esophagus, not for squamous cell carcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma.

Risk factors for SCC:

  • Tobacco
  • Alcohol
  • HPV
  • Plummer–Vinson syndrome
  • Achalasia
  • Tylosis
  • Caustic ingestion

Risk factors for adenocarcinoma:

  • Barrett's esophagus
  • GERD
  • Smoking
  • Obesity

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.solution:
Mucus-secreting goblet cells (not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus, as there is intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus. Foveolar cells are the mucus-secreting cells in the stomach.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and it is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60 years represent the highest-risk group.

Intestinal metaplasia in the esophagus occurs due to chronic irritation of the esophagus in GERD (option A) since intestinal epithelium is better suited to handling gastric acid exposure. Hence, mucus-secreting goblet cells are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus. Since all metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible (option D). Only 0.2 to 1% of Barrett's esophagus leads to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.

Alician blue is used in the staining of the biopsy specimen, as it stains the goblet cells (option C). Mucicarmine is the specific stain.

Seattle protocol is used for the management of Barrett's esophagus.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for cardia metaplasia in Barrett's esophagus is
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for Barrett's esophagus showing cardia metaplasia is endoscopy with methylene blue.

Barrett's esophagus is a metaplastic change (squamous to columnar change) in the lower end of the esophagus as a result of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease.

 Barrett’s esophagus can be-

  • Classical Barrett's esophagus - > 3cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.
  • Short segment  Barrett's esophagus - < 3cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.
  • Cardia metaplasia - microscopic Barrett’s in the GE junction. In cardia metaplasia due to lack of macroscopic changes, an endoscopic biopsy is difficult. So chromoendoscopy is the ideal investigation. Here mucosa is first stained by methylene blue to highlight abnormal mucosa.

Investigation of choice: endoscopic biopsy

Management: Seattle protocol is ideally followed to detect early dysplastic changes in Barrett's esophagus. Here a 4 quadrant biopsy specimen is taken 1- 2 cm apart throughout the area of intestinal metaplasia.

  • No signs of dysplasia - continue 2 yearly surveillance. 
  • Low-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 6 monthly surveillance.
  • High-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 3 monthly surveillance.

APC - Argon photo coagulation

RFA - Radiofrequency ablation

EMR - Endoscopic mucosal resection

Lugol’s iodine is used for squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Endoscopic biopsy of a patient with GERD revealed high-grade dysplasia of esophageal mucosa proximal to the GE junction. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Radiofrequency ablation and 6 monthly follow up
No intervention now and follow up every 2 years
Argon photocoagulation and 3 monthly follow up

questions.solution:
Ablation of abnormal mucosa and 3 monthly endoscopic protocol is the appropriate management in cases of high-grade dysplasia of esophageal mucosa due to GERD.

Studies suggest that patients with GERD have suggested that the right lateral decubitus position is associated with a higher oesophagal acid exposure time compared with the left lateral decubitus position.⁠

questions.text: An 80-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. The tumor is present in the distal esophagus, within 1 to 5 cm above the gastroesophageal junction. According to the Siewert classification, which type does this tumor belong to?
questions.solution:
Siewert type I lesions include tumors of the distal esophagus with the center located within 1 - 5 cm above the anatomic esophagogastric junction.

Related Pearl: Siewert-Stein classification of adenocarcinomas of the esophago-gastric junction

Siewert Description Surgical approach
I Tumour center located between 5 and 1 cm proximal to the anatomical cardia Approached as esophageal or EGJ cancer
II Tumour center located between 1 cm proximal and 2 cm distal to the anatomical cardia Approached as esophageal or EGJ cancer
III Tumour center located between 2 and 5 cm distal to the anatomical cardia Approached as gastric cancer

questions.text: An elderly male presented with significant weight loss and an inability to swallow food. A barium swallow was done and showed the following. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Dysphagia is the most common symptom
T1a tumor is restricted to sub mucosa
Barium swallow shows rat tail appearance
Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is used to confirm diagnosis

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with rat-tail appearance on barium swallow is suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. T1a tumor is restricted to the muscularis mucosa.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. 

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

 Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other Investigations include barium swallow which shows a rat-tail appearance  due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the conduit in gastric pull up done during esophagectomy?

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries
Right gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries
Left gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries
Left gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries

questions.solution:
The blood supply to the gastric conduit is based on the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries.

A gastric pull-up is done during esophagectomy for esophageal carcinoma. It is a surgical procedure where the stomach is pulled up into the thoracic cavity that now acts as a new passage (conduit) instead of the esophagus. 

During the esophagectomy,  the proximal stomach and lymph nodes are typically resected along with the segment of the esophagus. The gastric conduit is then fashioned by tubularization of the stomach. The right gastroepiploic artery is preserved and the other arteries are ligated to make ample length and mobility for the conduit. 

It is of utmost importance the right gastroepiploic artery is preserved as ischemia to the stomach will result in anastomotic leakage, stricture, and even dehiscence.  The rich supply of submucosal vascular networks can preserve the stomach on this single vessel. 

Approaches of esophagectomy:

1. Mckeown approach 

  • Done for upper 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd tumors (above aortic arch)
  • Anastomosis site is in the neck
  • Three incisions made (abdominal, thoracic, and left neck)

2. Transhiatal approach (Orringer)

  • Done for tumor of lower 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd of the esophagus 
  • Anastomosis site is in the neck
  • The most common complication is atelectasis and mortality is due to an anastomotic leak

3. Ivor lewis approach

  • Done for mid 1/3rd(below aortic arch) and lower 1/3rd esophagus tumors
  • Anastomosis site is in the thorax 

Related Pearl: Replacement conduits after esophagectomy

  • Best conduit after esophagectomy – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after carcinoma esophagus resection – Stomach
  • Best conduit of choice after benign disorders – Colon
  • Best conduit of choice after short segment replacement – Jejunum
  • Gastric conduit is based on right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries
  • Left colon conduit is based on left colic artery
  • The posterior mediastinal route is preferred for placement of conduit as it is the shortest route.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is diagnosed with esophageal carcinoma. Radiological investigations show a 2 cm tumor in the middle part of the esophagus. The tumor extends up to the submucosa with the involvement of mediastinal lymph nodes, there is no distant metastasis. What is the best treatment modality in his case?
questions.solution:
Chemoradiation followed by esophagectomy is the best treatment modality for tumors extending to the submucosa (T1b) with regional lymph node involvement (N1).

EMR (endoscopic mucosal resection) is done for small tumors confined to the mucosa, with no lymph node involvement. (T1aN0)

Esophagectomy ± chemoradiation is done when the tumor extends into the submucosa, with no lymph node involvement.

Chemoradiation followed by esophagectomy is done for tumors extending into the submucosa or beyond with lymph node enlargement

Chemoradiation therapy alone is done as a palliative measure in case of advanced esophageal carcinoma or in those patients unfit for surgery.

Esophageal stent placement is done in patients with advanced cancer and severe dysphagia that is not resolved by chemoradiation therapy. SEMS (self-expanding metallic stent) is the treatment of choice in malignant tracheoesophageal fistula.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with a history of dysphagia and weight loss for the past 1 year. Endoscopic ultrasonography done showed a tumor of size 4 cm in the mid esophagus above the aortic arch. Which of the following is the best approach?
questions.solution:
The best surgical approach for a mid-esophageal carcinoma above the aortic arch is  Mckeown’s esophagectomy.

 Approaches of esophagectomy:

1. Mckeown's approach 

  • Done for upper 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd tumors (above aortic arch)
  •  Anastomosis site is in the neck
  • Three incisions were made (abdominal, thoracic, and left neck)

2. Transhiatal approach (Orringer's approach)

  • Done for tumor of lower 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd of the esophagus 
  • Anastomosis site is in the neck

3. Ivor Lewis approach

  • Done for mid 1/3rd(below aortic arch) and lower 1/3rd esophagus tumors
  • Anastomosis site is in the thorax 
  • The most common complication is atelectasis 
  • The most common cause of mortality is due to an anastomotic leak leading to mediastinitis.

In esophagectomy, a proximal margin of 10cm and a distal margin of 5cm is taken.

questions.text: An male patient with stage IV esophageal carcinoma is taken up for esophageal stent insertion as a palliative measure. Which of the following is the most common complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of placing a stent in the esophagus is the migration of the stent.

Palliative treatment in advanced stages of esophageal carcinoma includes esophageal stent placement, enteral nutrition support, or the use of chemotherapy and radiation.

Complications of esophageal stent placement:

  • Migration of stent (most common)
  • Odynophagia
  • Tumour ingrowth and overgrowth
  • Chest pain
  • Severe reflux
